description.narrative: Political Stabilization and Reform through Confidence Building and Inclusive Dialogue.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Indicator 1.1.1: Intervention Strategy Developed Indicator 1.1.2: High level Forum held Indicator 1.1.3: Crisis Management for High Level Actors held Indicator 1.2.1: Civil Society Crisis Strategy developed that diminished distrust among CSOs and enables them to contribute to stabilization Indicator 1.2.2: Crisis Management Training for Civil Society held Indicator 1.2.3: Stabilizing Strategies implemented by CSO organizations Indicator 1.3.1: # of advocacy meetings held with political parties in efforts to facilitate political agreement on key political disputed issue Indicator 2.1.1: Draft Reforms laws written with stakeholder input Indicator 2.1.2: National Consultation held on 3 draft law Indicator 2.1.5 # of regional consultations held to produce thematic reports and # of CSOs members of the Network involved in the organization of those consultation Indicator 2.2.1.1: Other sources of funding which contribute to the Academy Indicator 2.2.1.2: Tailored training held for Stakeholder groups Indicator 2.2.2: Regional Stakeholder Consultations held Indicator 2.3.1: Diverse Delegates participate in National Conference (INDICATORS FOR OUTPUT 2.3 WILL CHANGE) Indicator 2.3.2: Preparation completed, and model options defined Indicator 2.3.4.1: Inclusive and participatory Conference Held and model chosen Indicator 2.3.4.2: Conference results are gender-sensitive

- The project is supporting the operationalization of the tripartite plan of action between ECOWAS, UNIOGBIS/UNDP and UNOWAS - Part of the UN Transition and Reconfiguration in Guinea-Bissau, which includes supporting efforts to foster effective inter-party and political leader´s dialogue via the created Good Offices Group of the National Assembly (ANP). - The Common Agenda (name agreed by the CSO instead of CSO Crisis Strategy) was agreed and it was launched on International Human Rights day on 10th December 2020 by 22 CSOs following the the creation of a Civil Society Concertation Space to push for peace and stability in the country. The Common Agenda was concluded with the participation of CSOs members in the regions (via a joint work with the EU) ensuring a more inclusive ownership of the process and not only a capital-city driven process. - As a direct COVID-19 response and a stabilization strategy implemented by CSO by enlarging political dialogue at community level, a Pilot initiative on community political dialogue in Bairro Militar, Bissau, was supported to facilitate dialogue between this community in Bairro Militar and authorities at local level on COVID-19 and other issues of importance for the community. This activity is being implemented through a partnership between 3 CSOs - Women Peace Security Network in ECOWAS (REMPSECAO), the National Youth Association (RENAJ) and the National Network of Young Women Leaders (RENAJELF). - The SRSG hold meetings with political parties to facilitate inclusive political dialogue and thus political stability: Two meetings with heads of political parties and two technical rounds to prepare the advocacy meetings. - The project developed an UN Roadmap to support the Constitutional Reform Process and a workshop of the ANP eventual constitutional revision commission took place in August/September, which was attended by MPs of all political benches as well as the technical members and Civil Society Organizations to conclude the draft on the revision of the constitution. Following the conclusion of its work, the commission nominated a team to reach out to the Presidential Committee and seek ways to bridge the two processes. - To ensure broader national consultations on the revision of Constitution, the Bissau-Guinean Association of Women’s Jurists is being supported in their advocacy and lobby strategy to ensure that specific-gender clauses are included in the revised version of the Constitution as well as mainstream gender throughout the document, which – if successfully, will have an impact in terms of gender equality and women´s empowerment in the country. In addition, an academic seminar was organized with the presence of national and international experts to share experiences regarding the revision of the Constitution during a 3 day-seminar and a report with recommendations was produced. - As per the Conakry agreement and following a request from the ANP President, the project is supporting the ANP Specialised Commission for judicial and constitutional affairs, human rights and public administration on the revision of the electoral and political parties’ laws. - Initial contacts and design to launch the Leadership Academyconcluded in partnership with the National Public Administration School in Bissau and its 3 polos in the regions, the Ubuntu Academy and key personalities in the country and with Instituto Pedro Pires in Cabo Verde. The Leadership Academy will operate in the capital and in the regions (face-to-face training at least in 3 regions) and via an online platform. As part of the Leadership Academy, UNDP set up together with MAVA Foundation, an Impact Hub in Bissau, as an incubator space to support and accompany agents of change in developing ideas with a social impact and transforming them into concrete and sustainable actions. - Implemented by WFP, in partnership with the NGO Tininguena, training was completed at community level in 11 communities, 11 women smallholder farmer’s associations and reaching 550 rural women in Gabu region. Under output 2.3 (reprogrammed - Increase awareness on reconciliation by addressing unsolved past griavances and promote a common understanding of the past), a grant was given to the Librarians and Documentalists Association, working in partnership with INEP who manages the national library, to collect and organize documents since the XVII century to ensure preservation of the national memory. All documents are now organized in shelves and the digitalization of the documents have started.
